scene.name: intro
scene.line: Busy night.
There he is again, sleeping. Where do I know him from? It's going to drive me up the wall.
Does he work at the university?
Oh, that sounds familiar ... Yeah, I think he might have worked there a long time ago. Maybe when I was an undergrad.
Ah, the `paleolithic`. I thought he looked a bit rugged.
That's right, Jenn, I went to college during the stone age.
What was your major?
Fire. I don't think he was a professor; maybe staff? It's been so long ... Sometimes, I wish I'd just barreled through — like you did — instead of taking time off before grad school.
Hm. I'm sure it was the right thing to do at the time.
Yeah ... or the `only` thing. I was such a mess. Did I ever tell you about that? My boyfriend died suddenly, in my last year of college.
Oh! Poor thing.
It's OK. It was a long time ago. But, yeah, it really shook me up, back then. He was studying . We were both really into experimental music. We took a few art classes together.
That's so sad. How did ... Sorry, never mind.

No, it's OK. That's the thing, actually — I mean, that's what shook me up about it — it was just this random accident that never should have happened, and so sudden you never could have seen it coming. He was back home, visiting his parents, and he fell off a roof!
Damn. I know what you mean. You can't predict that kind of ... what do you call it ... "freak accident" kind of thing.
My psychiatrist says that's why I'm such a pessimist.
Well, I think you're remarkably upbeat, all things considered ... I mean, you know, that thing with your boyfriend and the roof, but also what happened to the TV station!
"Acts of God."
You think?
No, I mean that's what you call it. That's what you say when it's nobody's fault.
